t: Psalm 78
Maschil of Asaph.
Give*p ear, O my people, to my law: incline your ears to the words of my mouth.
I*p will open my mouth in a parable: I will utter dark sayings of old:
Which*p we have heard and known, and our fathers have told us.
We*p will not hide them from their children, shewing to the generation to come the praises of the Lord,*s and his strength, and his wonderful works that he hath done.
For*p he established a testimony in Jacob, and appointed a law in Israel, which he commanded our fathers, that they should make them known to their children:
That*p the generation to come might know them, even the children which should be born; who should arise and declare them to their children:
That*p they might set their hope in God, and not forget the works of God, but keep his commandments:
And*p might not be as their fathers, a stubborn and rebellious generation; a generation that set not their heart aright, and whose spirit was not stedfast with God.
The*p children of Ephraim, being armed, and carrying bows, turned back in the day of battle.
They*p kept not the covenant of God, and refused to walk in his law;
And*p forgat his works, and his wonders that he had shewed them.
Marvellous*p things did he in the sight of their fathers, in the land of Egypt, in the field of Zoan.
He*p divided the sea, and caused them to pass through; and he made the waters to stand as an heap.
In*p the daytime also he led them with a cloud, and all the night with a light of fire.
He*p clave the rocks in the wilderness, and gave them drink as out of the great depths.
He*p brought streams also out of the rock, and caused waters to run down like rivers.
And*p they sinned yet more against him by provoking the most High in the wilderness.
And*p they tempted God in their heart by asking meat for their lust.
Yea,*p they spake against God; they said, Can God furnish a table in the wilderness?
Behold,*p he smote the rock, that the waters gushed out, and the streams overflowed; can he give bread also? can he provide flesh for his people?
Therefore*p the Lord*s heard this, and was wroth: so a fire was kindled against Jacob, and anger also came up against Israel;
Because*p they believed not in God, and trusted not in his salvation:
Though*p he had commanded the clouds from above, and opened the doors of heaven,
And*p had rained down manna upon them to eat, and had given them of the corn of heaven.
Man*p did eat angels' food: he sent them meat to the full.
He*p caused an east wind to blow in the heaven: and by his power he brought in the south wind.
He*p rained flesh also upon them as dust, and feathered fowls like as the sand of the sea:
And*p he let it fall in the midst of their camp, round about their habitations.
So*p they did eat, and were well filled: for he gave them their own desire;
They*p were not estranged from their lust. But while their meat was yet in their mouths,
The*p wrath of God came upon them, and slew the fattest of them, and smote down the chosen men of Israel.
For*p all this they sinned still, and believed not for his wondrous works.
Therefore*p their days did he consume in vanity, and their years in trouble.
When*p he slew them, then they sought him: and they returned and enquired early after God.
And*p they remembered that God was their rock, and the high God their redeemer.
Nevertheless*p they did flatter him with their mouth, and they lied unto him with their tongues.
For*p their heart was not right with him, neither were they stedfast in his covenant.
But*p he, being full of compassion, forgave their iniquity, and destroyed them not: yea, many a time turned he his anger away, and did not stir up all his wrath.
For*p he remembered that they were but flesh; a wind that passeth away, and cometh not again.
How*p oft did they provoke him in the wilderness, and grieve him in the desert!
Yea,*p they turned back and tempted God, and limited the Holy One of Israel.
They*p remembered not his hand, nor the day when he delivered them from the enemy.
How*p he had wrought his signs in Egypt, and his wonders in the field of Zoan:
And*p had turned their rivers into blood; and their floods, that they could not drink.
He*p sent divers sorts of flies among them, which devoured them; and frogs, which destroyed them.
He*p gave also their increase unto the caterpiller, and their labour unto the locust.
He*p destroyed their vines with hail, and their sycomore trees with frost.
He*p gave up their cattle also to the hail, and their flocks to hot thunderbolts.
He*p cast upon them the fierceness of his anger, wrath, and indignation, and trouble, by sending evil angels among them.
He*p made a way to his anger; he spared not their soul from death, but gave their life over to the pestilence;
And*p smote all the firstborn in Egypt; the chief of their strength in the tabernacles of Ham:
But*p made his own people to go forth like sheep, and guided them in the wilderness like a flock.
And*p he led them on safely, so that they feared not: but the sea overwhelmed their enemies.
And*p he brought them to the border of his sanctuary, even to this mountain, which his right hand had purchased.
He*p cast out the heathen also before them, and divided them an inheritance by line, and made the tribes of Israel to dwell in their tents.
Yet*p they tempted and provoked the most high God, and kept not his testimonies:
But*p turned back, and dealt unfaithfully like their fathers: they were turned aside like a deceitful bow.
For*p they provoked him to anger with their high places, and moved him to jealousy with their graven images.
When*p God heard this, he was wroth, and greatly abhorred Israel:
So*p that he forsook the tabernacle of Shiloh, the tent which he placed among men;
And*p delivered his strength into captivity, and his glory into the enemy's hand.
He*p gave his people over also unto the sword; and was wroth with his inheritance.
The*p fire consumed their young men; and their maidens were not given to marriage.
Their*p priests fell by the sword; and their widows made no lamentation.
Then*p the Lord awaked as one out of sleep, and like a mighty man that shouteth by reason of wine.
And*p he smote his enemies in the hinder parts: he put them to a perpetual reproach.
Moreover*p he refused the tabernacle of Joseph, and chose not the tribe of Ephraim:
But*p chose the tribe of Judah, the mount Zion which he loved.
And*p he built his sanctuary like high palaces, like the earth which he hath established for ever.
He*p chose David also his servant, and took him from the sheepfolds:
From*p following the ewes great with young he brought him to feed Jacob his people, and Israel his inheritance.
So*p he fed them according to the integrity of his heart; and guided them by the skilfulness of his hands.
